questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10 tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria and LFTs are deranged. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. N-acetylcysteine

 

The patient presents with signs of paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose, indicated by the ingestion of a high dose, deranged liver function tests (LFTs), and oliguria. Paracetamol overdose can lead to severe hepatotoxicity and acute liver failure.

 

N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for paracetamol toxicity. It works by replenishing glutathione stores, enhancing non-toxic metabolism of paracetamol, and reducing the formation of harmful metabolites. Early administration of N-acetylcysteine significantly reduces the risk of liver damage and improves outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine: Dopamine is used in the management of shock to improve renal perfusion and cardiac output. It is not indicated in the treatment of paracetamol toxicity and does not address the underlying hepatic damage.

 

Option C. Ursodeoxycholic acid: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used in the treatment of certain cholestatic liver diseases to improve bile flow. It does not play a role in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage fluid overload conditions such as heart failure or renal failure. It does not address the hepatotoxicity caused by paracetamol overdose and is not part of the standard treatment protocol for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of paracetamol toxicity, the antidote of choice is N-acetylcysteine, which should be administered as soon as possible to mitigate liver damage and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

The patient's laboratory findings show high urine osmolality and low serum osmolality, which are indicative of a condition where the kidneys are concentrating urine despite low blood osmolality. This is characteristic of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion.

 

In SIADH, excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia (low serum sodium), and the production of concentrated urine (high urine osmolality). The body retains water, which dilutes the blood sodium levels but the kidneys continue to excrete sodium, resulting in a low serum osmolality.

 

Differential diagnosis - Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome (CSWS):

 

  • Fluid Status: Patients are hypovolemic, meaning there is a reduced volume of circulating fluid in the body.
  • Characteristics: It involves the loss of sodium from the body, which exceeds the loss of water, leading to hyponatremia and decreased blood volume. This condition is often associated with neurological disorders such as injuries or diseases affecting the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia refers to high sodium levels in the blood, which would typically be associated with high serum osmolality. This does not fit the patient's laboratory findings.

 

Option C. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is an elevated level of potassium in the blood and does not correlate with the osmolality findings presented.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia is a low potassium level in the blood and, while it can be associated with various conditions, it is not directly indicated by the osmolality findings described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality, SIADH is a likely diagnosis, and the primary electrolyte abnormality to expect is hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following terms describes nuclides that have identical atomic mass numbers but different atomic numbers? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B (Isobars)

 

Explanation:

 

Isobars are nuclides that have the same mass number (A) but different atomic numbers (Z). This means they have the same total number of protons and neutrons, but the distribution between protons and neutrons differs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isotopes - Isotopes are different forms of the same element (same atomic number/Z) with different numbers of neutrons, resulting in different mass numbers (A). Isotopes have identical chemical properties but different physical properties due to their different masses.

 

Option C. Isotones - Isotones are nuclides that have the same number of neutrons but different numbers of protons. This results in different elements with different mass numbers but the same neutron count.

 

Option D. Isomers - Isomers are nuclides with identical atomic numbers (Z) and mass numbers (A), but different nuclear energy states. An example is Technetium-99m, where the "m" denotes a metastable state with higher energy than the ground state Technetium-99.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isobars are different elements with the same mass number but different atomic numbers, representing nuclides with the same total number of nucleons but different proton-to-neutron ratios.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of the boy with recurrent skin and respiratory infections, atopic excoriating skin, and notably, cold abscesses, strongly points towards Hyper IgE syndrome, also known as Job's syndrome. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • High levels of IgE: Elevated IgE is a hallmark of the syndrome and contributes to the immune dysregulation seen in these patients.
  • Recurrent infections: Due to defects in immune regulation, particularly affecting the response of neutrophils and other immune cells.
  • Dermatologic issues: Such as eczema and atopic dermatitis are common and often severe in these patients.
  • Genetic background: Hyper IgE syndrome is commonly caused by mutations in the STAT3 gene, which is critical for many aspects of immune system function, including the development and function of neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgM syndrome: Incorrect, characterized by elevated levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins, leading to a susceptibility to infections. It does not typically present with high IgE levels or eczema.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Incorrect, this is a condition that affects blood cells and immune response, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections; however, it does not typically involve high levels of IgE or cold abscesses.

 

Option D. Carcinoid syndrome: Incorrect, typically presents with symptoms caused by secreted hormones, such as flushing, diarrhea, and heart valve problems, which are unrelated to the immune dysfunction seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgE syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of high IgE levels, recurrent skin and respiratory infections, and dermatologic issues such as eczema. Managing this condition often involves addressing the skin care comprehensively and preventing infections through vigilant monitoring and appropriate use of antibiotics.

questions.text: Which medium is best suited for the transport of Streptococcus Pyogenes? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Pike's Medium

 

Explanation

 

Pike's medium is the specialized transport medium for Streptococcus pyogenes. This medium contains blood agar with crystal violet (1 in 1,000,000) and sodium azide (1 in 16,000), which creates selective conditions that inhibit competing bacteria while maintaining the viability of S. pyogenes during transport. These properties make it the optimal choice for transporting specimens suspected to contain this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stuart's Medium - Stuart's transport medium is designed for handling Neisseria specimens, particularly N. gonorrhoeae. While it's effective for many fastidious organisms, it's not specifically optimized for S. pyogenes transport.

 

Option C. Cary Blair Media - This medium is formulated for enteric pathogens, particularly Vibrio species and Yersinia pestis. Its high pH and low nutrient content make it unsuitable for the optimal transport of S. pyogenes.

 

Option D. Sach's Media - "Sach's buffered glycerol saline" is specifically designed for Shigella specimens. Its composition is not optimized for preserving streptococci during transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pike's medium provides the selective environment necessary for maintaining S. pyogenes viability during specimen transport while preventing overgrowth of contaminating flora.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman undergoes screening mammography. The figure suggests a likely diagnosis of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B (Involuting Fibroadenoma)

 

Explanation: 

 

The mammogram shows coarse, popcorn-like calcifications within a well-circumscribed mass. This characteristic "popcorn" pattern of calcification is the classic radiographic appearance of an involuting fibroadenoma. These benign breast tumors typically develop in younger women and often undergo calcification during the involution process as women age, particularly after menopause.

 

Visual Support: The image demonstrates the typical popcorn calcification pattern within a well-defined mass - the hallmark radiographic appearance of an involuting fibroadenoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intraductal Carcinoma Breast - Incorrect because DCIS typically presents with fine, linear, branching or pleomorphic microcalcifications in a segmental or ductal distribution, not the coarse popcorn-like calcifications seen here.

 

Option C. Fibroadenosis - Incorrect as fibroadenosis (fibrocystic changes) typically shows multiple small cysts and areas of increased density without the characteristic popcorn calcifications visible in this image.

 

Option D. Fat Necrosis - Incorrect because fat necrosis typically appears as an oil cyst with a thin calcified rim, or as spiculated masses with architectural distortion. It lacks the typical popcorn calcification pattern seen in this mammogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarse "popcorn" calcifications within a well-circumscribed mass on mammography are pathognomonic for an involuting fibroadenoma, representing the degenerative calcification of a previously non-calcified fibroadenoma.

questions.text: Which chromosome is involved in myotonic dystrophy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromosome 19

 

Myotonic dystrophy is an inherited genetic disorder that affects muscle function. It is caused by an abnormal expansion of nucleotide repeats in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19.

 

Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is a type of muscular dystrophy, a group of genetic disorders that cause progressive muscle loss and weakness. In DM, muscles are often unable to relax after contraction. Other manifestations may include cataracts, intellectual disability and heart conduction problems. In men, there may be early balding and an inability to father children. While myotonic dystrophy can occur at any age, onset is typically in the 20s and 30s.

 

There is no cure. Treatments may include braces or wheelchairs, pacemakers and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation. The medications mexiletine or carbamazepine can help relax muscles. Pain, if it occurs, may be treated with tricyclic antidepressants and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chromosome 20, Option C. Chromosome 21 and Option D. Chromosome 22: These chromosomes are not associated with the mutation causing myotonic dystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myotonic dystrophy is linked to a mutation in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19, leading to diverse symptoms including muscle dysfunction, cataracts, and cardiac issues.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department with head trauma due to a road traffic accident. In the hospital, the patient developed seizures. An emergency CT scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in cases of traumatic brain injury, like the one described. Mannitol works by creating an osmotic gradient that draws fluid out of the brain parenchyma and into the intravascular space, thereby reducing intracranial pressure and alleviating cerebral edema. This makes it the first-line treatment in emergency situations involving cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by antagonizing aldosterone in the distal nephron. It is not effective in managing cerebral edema and is primarily used in conditions like heart failure and certain cases of hyperaldosteronism.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is effective in treating peripheral and pulmonary edema by inhibiting the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the loop of Henle. While it is a potent diuretic, it is not the first choice for cerebral edema because it does not effectively lower intracranial pressure as mannitol does.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used mainly for hypertension and mild fluid retention. It is not used in the treatment of cerebral edema and would not be effective in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mannitol is the diuretic of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in emergency settings following traumatic brain injury, due to its ability to reduce intracranial pressure by drawing fluid out of the brain tissue.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What’s that compound? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligomycin

 

  • Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits ATP synthase, a key enzyme complex in oxidative phosphorylation. It blocks the flow of protons (H+) through ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis. As a result, adding oligomycin would indeed decrease oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a reduction in ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): 2,4-dinitrophenol is a chemical uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation. It disrupts the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, making it leaky to protons. This uncoupling reduces the efficiency of ATP production but doesn't directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from ubiquinone to cytochrome c, disrupting the electron flow in the chain.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I in the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, disrupting electron flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 123

questions.text: All of the following features of the genetic code are true, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Overlapping

 

Explanation:

 

The genetic code is not overlapping. In the genetic code, each codon (three-nucleotide sequence) specifies a particular amino acid, and each nucleotide belongs to only one codon. The code is read in a continuous sequence without overlap between adjacent codons. The non-overlapping nature of the genetic code means that the codon is read from a fixed starting point as a continuous sequence of bases, taking three at a time, without any punctuation between codons.

 

For example, the sequence AUCGGGACUGCA will be read as AUC GGG ACU GCA, with each nucleotide belonging exclusively to one codon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Degenerate: This is a correct feature of the genetic code. Degeneracy refers to the fact that most amino acids are coded by more than one codon. This property allows for some mutations to occur without changing the amino acid sequence of the protein.

 

Option C. Universal: This is a correct feature. The genetic code is largely universal across all organisms with only slight differences. This universality is strong evidence for the common evolutionary origin of all life on Earth.

 

Option D. Non-Punctuated: This is a correct feature. The genetic code is commaless, meaning there are no specific nucleotides that serve as punctuation marks between codons. Codons are read continuously without breaks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The genetic code is degenerate (multiple codons can code for the same amino acid), universal (largely conserved across species), and non-punctuated (read continuously), but it is NOT overlapping – each nucleotide is part of only one codon in the reading sequence.

questions.text: A Registered Medical Professional (RMP) is qualified to perform an MTP in the first trimester if he has assisted in the following number of MTPs: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25

 

A Registered Medical Practitioner (RMP) must have assisted in at least 25 MTPs in an authorized center to be qualified to perform MTPs independently. This requirement is part of the MTP Act which defines who can legally perform medical termination of pregnancy procedures. This is one of three qualifying criteria along with having a diploma/degree in Obs & Gyn or completing 6 months house surgeon training in Obs & Gyn.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5: This number is too low and does not meet the minimum requirement established by the MTP Act for practical experience.

 

Option B. 15: While closer to the required number, this falls short of the minimum 25 assisted procedures needed for qualification.

 

Option D. 50: This exceeds the minimum requirement specified in the MTP Act. While additional experience is beneficial, only 25 assisted procedures are legally required.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The MTP Act requires an RMP to have assisted in at least 25 MTPs in an authorized center as one of the key criteria to ensure adequate procedural experience before performing independent procedures.

questions.text: The X Ray of the skull as shown in the image given below is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperparathyroidism

 

The given image is the X-ray of the skull is salt and pepper appearance which shows multiple tiny radiolucent lytic lesions due to resorption of the bone by PTH, seen in hyperparathyroidism. There is also a loss of definition between the skull's inner and outer tables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma could also show lytic lesions; however, these are typically larger "punched-out" lesions rather than the fine stippling seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Hyperthyroidism primarily affects soft tissue and can lead to osteoporosis but does not typically show the "salt and pepper" skull appearance.

 

Option D. Paget's disease: Paget's disease of the bone leads to enlarged and misshapen bones due to excessive breakdown and formation of bone. X-rays might show thickening of the bones rather than the fine stippling of hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiological skull features of hyperparathyroidism are:

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Plasmodium falciparum is identified in the peripheral smear by the presence of multiple rings within a single red blood cell (RBC) and the characteristic headphone-like structure known as the accolé form or appliqué form. In the provided image, multiple rings are visible in some RBCs, and a distinctive headphone-like structure can be observed, which are hallmarks of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium vivax: This species typically shows a single ring per RBC and can form larger, amoeboid shapes in the late trophozoite stage, which are not seen in this image.

 

Option C. Plasmodium ovale: This species also shows a single ring per RBC and is often characterized by an oval shape of the infected RBC and ragged cell edges, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Plasmodium malariae: This species shows a band form of the trophozoite across the RBC, which is not present in the image. It also typically has fewer merozoites in the schizont stage compared to Plasmodium falciparum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmodium falciparum can be distinguished by the presence of multiple rings in a single RBC and the characteristic headphone-like accolé form.

questions.text: The mosaic pattern of cement lines is characteristically seen in which of the following bone conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Paget's disease of bone

 

Explanation: 

 

Paget's disease of bone is characterized by excessive and abnormal bone remodeling, with initial osteoclastic bone resorption followed by excessive osteoblastic bone formation. This chaotic remodeling process creates a distinctive microscopic appearance known as a "mosaic pattern" of cement lines that resembles a jigsaw puzzle. These cement lines represent the reversal lines between areas of bone resorption and subsequent formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism - While hyperthyroidism can increase bone turnover and lead to osteoporosis, it does not produce the characteristic mosaic pattern of cement lines seen in Paget's disease. Hyperthyroidism causes generalized bone loss rather than the focal abnormal remodeling seen in Paget's disease.

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy - This is a complex bone disorder associated with chronic kidney disease. It can cause various bone abnormalities including secondary hyperparathyroidism, osteomalacia, and adynamic bone disease, but the characteristic mosaic pattern of cement lines is not a feature.

 

Option D. Osteomalacia - This condition is characterized by inadequate mineralization of bone matrix (osteoid) due to vitamin D deficiency or abnormal vitamin D metabolism. It shows increased unmineralized osteoid and inadequate calcification, not a mosaic pattern of cement lines.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The mosaic pattern of cement lines is a pathognomonic histological feature of Paget's disease of bone, reflecting the chaotic and accelerated bone remodeling process that characterizes this condition.

choices.text: Switch to low molecular weight heparin

questions.text: A pregnant female at 37 weeks of gestation with a history of prosthetic heart valves is currently taking warfarin. She comes for a routine antenatal check-up. What is the appropriate management advice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Switch to low molecular weight heparin

 

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that is commonly used in patients with prosthetic heart valves to prevent thromboembolic events. However, warfarin is known to cross the placenta and can cause fetal complications, particularly when used during the first trimester. It is also associated with an increased risk of bleeding during delivery if continued into the third trimester.

 

The standard management of anticoagulation in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves involves switching from warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as delivery approaches. LMWH is preferred during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester and after 36 weeks of gestation, due to its safety profile and because it does not cross the placenta.

 

In this case, at 37 weeks of gestation, it is important to switch from warfarin to LMWH to reduce the risk of bleeding complications during delivery and to avoid any adverse effects on the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate induction of labor: Induction of labor may be considered under specific conditions but is not the first-line management for anticoagulation issues.

 

Option B. Perform LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): A cesarean section might be necessary based on obstetric indications but is not related to the management of anticoagulation in this context.

 

Option C. Continue the same medication: Continuing warfarin at 37 weeks is not recommended due to the risks of bleeding during delivery and potential harm to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves:

 

1st Trimester – LMWH

2nd Trimester – LMWH >> Warfarin

3rd Trimester –  LMWH

Overall best option - LMWH

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, but the right heart valves may also be involved in some cases.

 

Vegetations can be single or multiple, with one or more valves involved. Embolization is common and, due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli, can result in septic infarctions or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgment.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

 

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis shows small, friable vegetations.

questions.text: There was outbreak of MRSA in the hospital, and it was found that a nurse of NICU had MRSA colonization of anterior nares. What is the best treatment?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Topical mupirocin

 

  • Anterior nares are the most common site of colonization in carrier state of MRSA.
  • Mupirocin (2% topical cream) is DOC for MRSA carriers. Other drug that can be used is topical Bacitracin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral Vancomycin: Vancomycin is typically used for systemic MRSA infections and is administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. It is not appropriate for eradicating nasal colonization.

 

Option C. Inhaled colistin: Colistin is used for multi-drug-resistant gram-negative infections and is not indicated for MRSA, especially not for nasal colonization.

 

Option D. IV cefazolin: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin effective against methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) but not MRSA. It is also not suitable for treating nasal colonization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For MRSA colonization in the anterior nares, topical mupirocin is the best treatment due to its targeted action, efficacy, and minimal systemic side effects.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/809

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block. In a matter of few seconds the patient suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the correct 1st line treatment of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra lipid infusion

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms of hypotension and arrhythmias after the administration of 0.5% bupivacaine suggest local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation in significant amounts. Intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) therapy is considered the first-line treatment for LAST. It works by creating a "lipid sink" that helps to sequester the lipophilic local anesthetic away from target organs, particularly the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive Ventilation: This is provided if the patient is not able to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation on their own. It is supportive care and does not directly counteract the toxicity of the local anesthetic.

 

Option C. Soda Bicarbonate (Sodium Bicarbonate): This can be used to treat metabolic acidosis, which may occur secondary to hypoxia or cardiac arrest. While it can help in the supportive management of LAST, it is not the first line for the toxicity itself.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPCR): This is initiated in the case of cardiac arrest. While it's a crucial component of resuscitation, it's not a first-line treatment for the toxicity unless the patient has progressed to cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy, which helps to reduce the systemic toxicity of lipophilic local anesthetic agents such as bupivacaine.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: Associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.

 

List of Oncogenic Microbe:

choices.text: Transition from infectious pandemic diseases to man-made diseases
Transition from low literacy levels to high literacy levels
Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate
Transition from unfavorable sex ratio to favorable sex ratio

questions.text: What is demographic transition as a country passes through the demographic cycle? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Transition from high birth rate & death rate to low birth rate & death rate

 

 

The demographic transition refers to the shift in a country’s population characteristics as it moves through different stages of the demographic cycle. The cycle typically includes five stages, starting with high birth and death rates (Stage 1), followed by declining death rates (Stage 2), declining birth rates (Stage 3), and eventually both low birth and death rates (Stage 4). This process reflects changes in a society’s economic and social conditions, such as improvements in healthcare, education, and overall living standards. The transition leads to slower population growth and ultimately stabilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition from infectious pandemic diseases to man-made diseases: This option describes the epidemiological transition, which refers to the shift in the types of prevalent diseases from infectious to chronic, non-communicable diseases as a society develops.

 

Option B. Transition from low literacy levels to high literacy levels: This option reflects educational and social changes within a population but does not specifically describe demographic transition.

 

Option D. Transition from unfavorable sex ratio to favorable sex ratio: This option describes changes in gender ratios, often due to social or policy influences, but it is not directly related to demographic transition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demographic transition is characterized by the shift from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country progresses through the stages of the demographic cycle.

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

 

The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies. It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in LATTICE FORMATION where the antigen-antibody interactions are equal, eventually giving rise to a positive result.

 

Lattice hypothesis: The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. The point where the antigen and the antibody are in the same amount , best interaction takes place in this zone called as the zone of equivalence. 

 

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete antibodies: These are not typically responsible for the phenomenon described. Incomplete antibodies generally do not cause agglutination but can bind antigens.

 

Option B. Complement inactivation: This would not typically result in the observed test pattern and is more relevant in tests involving complement fixation.

 

Option D. Post-zone phenomenon: Occurs when there is an excess of antigen, not antibodies, leading to a lack of visible agglutination due to insufficient cross-linking by antibodies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The prozone phenomenon, responsible for initial false-negative results in serological tests like the standard agglutination test for brucellosis, occurs due to excessive antibodies preventing visible agglutination. This can be corrected by diluting the serum, which highlights the importance of considering antibody concentration in diagnostic testing.

questions.text: Leading questions can be allowed in? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross Examination

 

Explanation:

 

Leading questions (questions whose answers can be given in yes/no format) are specifically allowed in:

 

  1. Cross examination
  2. Dying deposition
     For example: "Has Ram killed Shyam?" is a leading question, while "Who killed Shyam?" is not This restriction helps ensure unbiased testimony during direct examination and re-examination​

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed in direct examination unless a witness becomes hostile

​

Option C. Re-Direct Examination: Incorrect. Leading questions are not permitted unless required to clarify contradictions arising from cross-examination​

 

Option D. Any Time: Incorrect. Leading questions are not allowed freely in all legal proceedings. They are only allowed in cross-examination and dying depositions​

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leading questions 


Ans can be given in Yes/ No
E.g.,
Has Suresh killed Madan? – is a leading question 
Who killed Madan? - It is not a leading question
 

Leading Questions


When leading conditions can be asked

  1. Dying deposition 
  2. Cross examination 
  3. As an exception in Examination in chief if witness turns hostile

     

When leading questions cannot be asked 

  1. Dying declaration 
  2. Examination in chief 
  3. Re – examination

questions.text: During pregnancy, pyogenic granuloma, also called granuloma gravidarum, most commonly arises from which location? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gingival papillae

 

Granuloma gravidarum (pyogenic granuloma) is a common gingival change during pregnancy. This highly vascular pedunculated lesion develops on the gums and may bleed profusely, which is why it's also known as epulis gravidarum. The condition develops due to hormonal changes of pregnancy, particularly increased estrogen levels causing increased vascularity and inflammatory response in the gingival tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tongue: Pyogenic granuloma during pregnancy specifically affects the gingival tissue, not the tongue. While oral changes do occur during pregnancy, the tongue is not the characteristic site for granuloma gravidarum.

 

Option C. Uvula: The uvula is not a typical site for pregnancy-related pyogenic granuloma. These vascular lesions specifically develop on the gingival tissue due to hormonal influences on gum vascularity.

 

Option D. Soft Palate: Soft palate involvement is not characteristic of granuloma gravidarum. These lesions have a predilection for the gingival tissue where they appear as red, bleeding masses on the gums.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma gravidarum (pregnancy epulis) is a highly vascular pedunculated lesion that develops on the gingiva during pregnancy and has a propensity to bleed profusely due to increased vascularity from hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with eclampsia is on a maintenance dose of MgSO₄. When will you stop MgSO₄? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine output 60ml in 4hr


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is used in eclampsia management to prevent seizures. However, MgSO₄ toxicity can occur, which necessitates stopping or adjusting the dose. The first sign of MgSO₄ toxicity is the absence of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), followed by respiratory depression and reduced urine output. Since magnesium is excreted through the kidneys, urine output is a critical measure of magnesium toxicity risk. A urine output of less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours) indicates poor excretion and potential toxicity, requiring immediate adjustment or cessation of MgSO₄.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee jerk present: The presence of a knee jerk (deep tendon reflex) is a positive sign and indicates that magnesium levels are not yet toxic. The absence of DTRs is the first indication of toxicity, so this is not a reason to stop MgSO₄.

 

Option B. RR 18/min: A respiratory rate above 10 breaths per minute is safe when on MgSO₄. Respiratory depression is a sign of advanced toxicity; therefore, a rate of 18 per minute is not concerning.

 

Option C. Visual disturbances: Visual disturbances are symptoms associated with eclampsia or pre-eclampsia (e.g., retinal detachment or blurred vision) but are not signs of MgSO₄ toxicity. These do not indicate the need to stop MgSO₄.

 

Educational Objective:


MgSO₄ should be stopped if the patient’s urine output is less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours), as this indicates poor excretion and risk of magnesium toxicity.

questions.text: At what period of gestation is the nuchal translucency measured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Nuchal translucency (NT) measurement is an ultrasound marker used for the screening of chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome (trisomy 21). The optimal time to measure NT is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation, more specifically between 11 weeks and 13 weeks and 6 days. During this period, the NT measurement is most accurate and predictive. The NT scan involves measuring the clear space in the tissue at the back of the baby's neck.

 

An absent Nasal Bone (NB) and increased NT measurement both are the marker of Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Nuchal translucency should be measured between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation to effectively screen for chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

questions.text: What type of stridor occur in croup?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biphasic stridor

 

Given the question is about croup, the correct answer is Biphasic stridor, because croup usually affects the subglottic region and can cause narrowing that affects both phases of breathing.

 

Biphasic stridor is heard during both inhalation and exhalation and indicates a narrowing at the level of the vocal cords or just below them in the subglottic region. This type of stridor is characteristic of croup, which typically affects the subglottic area of the larynx.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound that occurs during inhalation. It is commonly associated with conditions that cause narrowing of the upper airway above the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Expiratory stridor is a wheezing sound heard during exhalation and is less common. It suggests a problem lower in the respiratory tract, such as the bronchioles or smaller bronchi.

 

Option D. No stridor would mean that there is no abnormal airway sound, which would not be applicable in the context of a discussion about croup, which typically presents with stridor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croup typically presents with biphasic stridor, which occurs during both inspiration and expiration, reflecting the subglottic airway narrowing characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: An individual undergoes a bone marrow examination which shows the presence of the cells as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely enzyme defect associated with this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The presence of gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease. It is caused by deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher's Disease:

 

  • Pathology: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside into glucose and ceramide.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bone pain or fractures.
  • Histopathology: Gaucher cells are macrophages filled with lipid-laden lysosomes. These cells have a characteristic crumpled paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hexosaminidase: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by a cherry-red spot on the macula.

 

Option C. Alpha 1,4 glucosidase: Deficiency causes Pompe disease, characterized by glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.

 

Option D. Galactosidase: Deficiency causes Fabry disease, characterized by angiokeratomas, acroparesthesia, and renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance in a bone marrow examination are indicative of Gaucher's disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher Disease Overview:

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 37 degrees C

 

Frostbite should be managed with rapid and complete thawing using a circulating water bath maintained between 37°C and 40°C. This temperature range is optimal to reverse vascular stasis and initiate reperfusion without causing thermal injury.

 

Thawing at this range is typically performed for 30 to 60 minutes and should be done only when the possibility of refreezing is excluded. Higher temperatures like 42°C are not recommended and may worsen tissue injury.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 42°C: Too hot. It exceeds the upper recommended limit and can risk thermal damage to already compromised tissue.

 

Option C. 32°C: Insufficient to produce effective rewarming. Rewarming would be slow and incomplete.

 

Option D. 30°C: Ineffective. Tissue remains partially frozen and vulnerable to re-freezing injury.

 

Educational Objective:


Frostbite should be rewarmed in circulating water at 37–40°C for 30–60 minutes, avoiding hot air or dry heat.

questions.text: Neurodegeneration with iron accumulation in the basal ganglia is typically seen in: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hallervorden-Spatz disease

 

Explanation:

 

Hallervorden-Spatz disease, now officially renamed as Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration (PANK), is characterized by excessive iron deposition in the basal ganglia, particularly in the globus pallidus and substantia nigra. This neurodegenerative disorder typically presents with dystonia, parkinsonism, and cognitive decline. The pathological hallmark is neurodegeneration with iron accumulation specifically in the basal ganglia regions. The characteristic "eye of the tiger" sign seen on MRI reflects the pattern of iron accumulation with central hyperintensity surrounded by hypointensity in the globus pallidus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemochromatosis - While hemochromatosis involves systemic iron overload affecting multiple organs (particularly liver, pancreas, heart, and joints), it does not typically cause significant neurodegeneration with iron accumulation in the basal ganglia. The CNS is relatively spared in this condition.

 

Option C. Wilson's Disease - This is characterized by abnormal copper metabolism and copper accumulation in various tissues including the brain, liver, and cornea. The basal ganglia are affected, but the pathology involves copper deposition, not iron accumulation. Wilson's disease can present with parkinsonism but through a different pathophysiological mechanism.

 

Option D. Cystic Fibrosis - This is a genetic disorder affecting primarily the lungs and pancreas. It has no association with iron accumulation in the basal ganglia or other brain regions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hallervorden-Spatz disease (PANK) is the classic example of neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation, specifically targeting the basal ganglia and resulting in a distinctive movement disorder with both dystonic and parkinsonian features.

choices.text: There is an incremental response on 2-3 Hz nerve stimulation
Antibodies are directed against voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCC)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. There is an incremental response on 2-3 Hz nerve stimulation

 

Explanation:

 

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a presynaptic disorder of the neuromuscular junction. In LEMS, at low rates of repetitive nerve stimulation (2-3 Hz), a decremental response is observed, similar to myasthenia gravis. However, at high rates of stimulation (20-50 Hz) or following brief exercise, an incremental response occurs, which is characteristic of LEMS. This distinguishes LEMS from myasthenia gravis. LEMS is caused by autoantibodies directed against P/Q-type calcium channels at motor nerve terminals, which impair acetylcholine release.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibodies are directed against voltage: gated calcium channels (VGCC) - This statement is correct. LEMS is caused by autoantibodies directed against P/Q-type calcium channels at the motor nerve terminals, detected in approximately 85% of LEMS patients. These autoantibodies impair the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

 

Option C. Reflexes are absent or depressed: This statement is correct. In LEMS, patients have depressed or absent reflexes, which is a distinguishing feature from myasthenia gravis.

 

Option D. Patients experience autonomic changes: This statement is correct. LEMS patients experience autonomic changes such as dry mouth and impotence, which are characteristic features of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In LEMS, a decremental response occurs at low rates of nerve stimulation (2-3 Hz), while an incremental response is seen at high rates of stimulation (20-50 Hz) or after brief exercise—this electrophysiologic pattern helps distinguish LEMS from myasthenia gravis.

choices.text: Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3 of ULN serum LDH
Pleural fluid protein-to-serum protein ratio more than 0.5
Pleural fluid LDH more than 0.6 of serum LDH

questions.text: A patient with a recent diagnosis of pneumonia presents with pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis is performed. Which of the following findings is not consistent with a diagnosis of exudative parapneumonic effusion? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleural fluid pH greater than 7.4

 

Explanation:

 

Parapneumonic effusions are exudative pleural effusions associated with pneumonia, lung abscess, or bronchiectasis.

 

Light’s criteria define exudates as having at least one of the following:

 

  • Pleural fluid LDH >2/3 of upper normal serum LDH
  • Pleural fluid protein-to-serum protein ratio >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio >0.6

 

Pleural fluid pH is typically <7.2 in complicated parapneumonic effusions and empyema.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B, and D – Correctly describe exudative effusions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exudative parapneumonic effusions meet at least one of Light’s criteria, and pH is usually <7.4.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided as he will have aspirin intolerance.

 

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

 

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

 

Aspirin and COX – 1 inhibitors can exacerbate asthma hence they should be avoided. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

 

The provocative challenge test with aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is the only diagnostic method.

 

Aspirin desensitization is an important therapeutic option in patients with ST, especially in those patients suffering from recurrent NPs, anosmia, and overdependence on systemic corticosteroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole and Option B. Co-amoxiclav: These are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections, including sinusitis, and do not affect COX-1 activity.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: An antibiotic that is generally used for serious infections where other antibiotics are not suitable. It does not interact with the COX-1 pathway.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

choices.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

 

Wound dehiscence is the partial or total separation of layers of a surgical wound. Various signs can indicate this complication, particularly in a post-operative patient who is hypotensive:

 

This type of drainage, which is composed of both blood and serous fluid, can indicate that the wound layers are not properly adhered and may be a sign of impending or actual dehiscence. It's considered a "sure sign" because it often precedes the wound actually coming apart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased bowel sounds: While changes in bowel sounds can be associated with various abdominal conditions like intestinal obstruction, they are not a specific sign of wound dehiscence.

 

Option B. Persistent abdominal pain: Pain is a nonspecific symptom that can be associated with many post-operative complications, including wound dehiscence, but on its own is not a definitive sign.

 

Option D. Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges: While this can occur with wound dehiscence, it is more of a late sign when the wound has already dehisced significantly.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Serosanguinous drainage from the surgical wound is a "sure sign" of wound dehiscence and warrants immediate medical evaluation to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Methotrexate acts by inhibiting: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dihydrofolate reductase

 

Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune system suppressant. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. This enzyme is crucial for the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a form of folic acid that is required for the synthesis of thymidylate, purines, and the amino acid methionine.

 

By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate effectively depletes the cell’s supply of tetrahydrofolate, which in turn inhibits DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis. This inhibition is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cells, which is why methotrexate is used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymidylate synthetase: Thymidylate synthetase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP) from deoxyuridylate (dUMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis. This enzyme is inhibited by 5-Fluorouracil, not methotrexate.

 

Option B. DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase is an enzyme responsible for forming new copies of DNA, but methotrexate does not directly inhibit this enzyme. Inhibition of DNA polymerase would prevent DNA replication, but methotrexate acts upstream in the folate pathway.

 

Option C. RNA Polymerase: RNA polymerase is responsible for synthesizing RNA from a DNA template. Methotrexate does not inhibit RNA polymerase; instead, it inhibits the production of necessary components for DNA and RNA synthesis indirectly by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, thereby preventing the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and breathlessness but was medically fit. The patient is refusing to go back home and he doesn’t want to leave the hospital. The patient gives a history of robbery under gun-point that happened 10 days ago. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute stress disorder

 

The patient experienced a traumatic event 10 days ago and is now presenting with anxiety symptoms, making acute stress disorder the most probable diagnosis.

 

Acute stress disorder is characterized by the development of severe anxiety and other symptoms within one month after exposure to an extreme traumatic stressor. These symptoms include intrusive thoughts, flashbacks, and avoidance behavior, although the given case focuses on anxiety.

 

The duration of symptoms is crucial: if symptoms persist for more than one month, the diagnosis shifts to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoidant personality disorder: This cannot be diagnosed based on a single event; it requires a lifelong pattern of behavior characterized by social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation.

 

Option B. Delusional disorder: This involves persistent delusions without other major psychotic symptoms. There is no mention of delusions in the patient's history.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia: This diagnosis requires symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and other psychotic behaviors persisting for at least six months. The patient's history does not suggest these symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute stress disorder occurs within one month of a traumatic event and is characterized by anxiety and other stress-related symptoms. If symptoms last longer than one month, the diagnosis changes to PTSD.

choices.text: Outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll

questions.text: In a case of drowning, the following organism was isolated from the internal organs. What is true regarding this organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll

 

The organism in question is a diatom, which is a type of unicellular microscopic algae commonly associated with drowning cases. Diatoms have a distinctive cell wall composed of silica, making them resistant to acidic environments. In drowning cases, if the water containing diatoms enters the body, these organisms can travel through the bloodstream and be found in various organs, including the bone marrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a unicellular bacteria: This statement is incorrect. Diatoms are unicellular algae, not bacteria. They are distinct in their structure and biological function.

 

Option B.  Not resistant to acid: This statement is incorrect. Diatoms have a silica-based cell wall, which is resistant to acid, allowing them to survive in harsh environments.

 

Option C.  Only present in bone marrow: While diatoms can be found in the bone marrow, especially in cases of drowning, they are not exclusive to this location. They can be distributed to other organs via the circulatory system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diatoms are unicellular algae with a silica-containing outer wall, making them resistant to acid and present in various organs in drowning cases.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: A person presents with clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers, accompanied by sensory loss at the tips of the same fingers. Which nerve is most commonly affected in this case? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar nerve

 

The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the intrinsic muscles of the hand, including the third and fourth lumbricals, which control the 4th and 5th fingers. A lesion of the ulnar nerve leads to ulnar claw hand, characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joints of the 4th and 5th fingers.

 

Additionally, sensory loss at the tips of the 4th and 5th fingers aligns with the cutaneous innervation of the ulnar nerve, which supplies the medial one and a half fingers (little finger and half of the ring finger), including their tips.

 

Ulnar nerve injury commonly occurs at:

 

  • The medial epicondyle of the humerus (fracture at this site can damage the ulnar nerve).
  • Guyon's canal (wrist level), which can be compressed in cyclists or due to repetitive trauma (Guyon canal syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial nerve: Incorrect because Radial nerve injury leads to wrist drop, affecting wrist and finger extension. It does not affect the intrinsic muscles of the hand or cause claw deformity.

 

Option C. Median nerve: Incorrect because median nerve supplies the lateral three and a half fingers (thumb, index, middle, and half of the ring finger) and controls the first and second lumbricals. Injury leads to "hand of benediction" when attempting to make a fist, rather than clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers.

 

Option D. Anterior Interosseous nerve: Incorrect because it’s a branch of the median nerve and primarily affects deep forearm muscles (flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus), leading to inability to form the "OK" sign (anterior interosseous syndrome). It does not cause clawing of the fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve injury leads to ulnar claw hand, which involves hyperextension at the MCP joints and flexion at the IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers, along with sensory loss in the medial one and a half fingers. The median nerve affects the lateral three and a half fingers, and the radial nerve controls wrist and finger extension.

 

Ulnar Claw hand - Ulnar nerve damage

 

Complete Claw hand - injury of both Ulnar and Median nerve.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Primary health center

 

  • In India, the School Health Committee recommended that school health services be integrated with general health services, which are managed by primary health centers (PHCs).
  • To ensure effective implementation, the committee proposed the formation of school health committees at various levels. PHCs are responsible for providing a range of school health services such as health assessments, vision and hearing tests, dental check-ups, treatment for common illnesses, immunization, micronutrient management, deworming, and provision of mid-day meals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.

questions.text: What is the term for the probability of infection occurring in susceptible individuals after they come into contact with an infectious person during the incubation period? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Secondary attack rate

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR): Is no. of exposed persons developing the disease within range of incubation period (IP), following exposure to the primary case

 

It is calculated by the following formula:

 

 

Primary case is excluded from both numerator & denominator

 

Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease / Infectivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Case fatality rate: This rate measures the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a particular disease who die from that disease within a specific period. It is a measure of the severity of the disease.

 

Option C. Primary attack rate: This rate refers to the proportion of the population that becomes ill after being exposed to an infectious agent for the first time. It does not specifically account for subsequent spread among contacts.

 

Option D. Tertiary attack rate: This term is not commonly used in epidemiology. It would imply further transmission beyond secondary contacts, but this is not a standard measure

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary attack rate is a crucial epidemiological measure for understanding the spread of infectious diseases among contacts of an initial case. It helps determine the infectivity and potential for outbreaks within a population.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency room with severe pain in the abdomen. Serum triglyceride level was 1500 mg/dL. Identify the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apo CII

 

The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and extremely elevated triglyceride levels (1500 mg/dL) suggests acute pancreatitis secondary to hypertriglyceridemia, commonly seen in Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia. This condition is characterized by a defect in the lipoprotein lipase (LPL) enzyme or its activator, Apo CII. Apo CII is essential for the activation of LPL, which breaks down triglycerides in the blood. A deficiency or defect in Apo CII prevents this activation, leading to the accumulation of triglycerides and increased risk of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo B 48: This apolipoprotein is essential for the formation of chylomicrons but does not play a role in lipase activation or triglyceride breakdown. Defects in Apo B 48 do not cause elevated triglyceride levels seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Apo B 100: Apo B 100 is critical for the formation of LDL and VLDL particles but does not contribute directly to triglyceride metabolism or cause the acute elevation of triglycerides leading to pancreatitis.

 

Option D. LDL receptor: Defects in LDL receptors are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to elevated LDL cholesterol levels, not triglycerides. It does not contribute to the type of severe hypertriglyceridemia seen in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, presenting with high triglycerides and abdominal pain, is often due to a defect in lipoprotein lipase or its activator, Apo CII.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoing treatment for tuberculosis reports experiencing a decrease in visual acuity and color blindness. Which of the following antitubercular drugs is most likely to cause visual problems? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that is known to cause optic neuritis, which is an inflammation of the optic nerve. This condition can lead to a decrease in visual acuity and color blindness, most notably red-green color blindness.

 

The mnemonic "E for Ethambutol, E for Eye problems" can be used to remember this association.

 

Ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is dose-dependent and can be reversible upon discontinuation of the drug, but if not identified early, it may result in permanent vision loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is associated with hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy, primarily due to its interference with vitamin B6 metabolism.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Rifampicin can cause orange discoloration of body fluids (urine, sweat, tears) and is a potent enzyme inducer, leading to multiple drug interactions.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is known to be hepatotoxic and can cause hyperuricemia, which may lead to gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis, leading to a decrease in visual acuity and red-green color blindness.
